    This is the personal homepage of Elad Meidar, a web developer and an entrepreneur specializing in Ruby on Rails. I hang around Fort Lauderdale, FL and Tel-Aviv in Israel, and i am currently running Nautilus6 so Feel free to contact me regarding projects :).

Bag O' Links - 13/10/2009

  • mrkris’s thoughts about code and pooping – @mrkris’s unique approach over life strikes again. today, how to take advantage a seat time for your professional life.
  • Realtime watch list tracker script – a nice jQuery plugin from pluginaweek that shows a tiny google graph with the watchers list of some github repos for your choice.
  • Vertical centering in CSS – some suggestions on how to solve that issue.
  • New on edge Rails – XSS escaping and some XML building enhancements are the jewels in today’s crown.
  • Mike Gunderloy’s tools of the Trade – Mike hardware and software overview.
  • and @hakunin’s too – looks like a trend here… maybe i should add mine. firearms included?
  • spidr – a ruby web crawler – Spidr is a versatile Ruby web spidering library that can spider a site, multiple domains, certain links or infinitely. Spidr is designed to be fast and easy to use.
  • will_paginate tricks – that blog shows some very nice tricks, if you don’t follow that one, do it now.
  • Cloud browser testing – definitely something worth checking out.
  • rendering HTML in canvas – first signs of what appears to be, a recipe for confusion among developers.
  • codepad – a pastebin that executes code.
  • Use a badge to distinct environments – a nice trick to setup a visual notation of your rails_env
  • Passenger with debugger – a +1 for development setups.
  • xCSS – Object oriented CSS framework – a straightforward and object-oriented workflow when developing complex style cascades.
  • CSS organizing method – order in your CSS files.
  • Easy roles in Rails – a nice gem (off gemcutter)
  • cucumber and unobtrusive javascript tests – win, now.. shoulda? please?
  • Switch to GemCutter – since github decided to drop gem support, gemcutter is the best thing around to use in this case. @qrush deserves the applause.
  • a Better scout – new release for this server and application monitoring tool.
  • riak# – another key value storage engine for the web.
  • Javascript skills you should have – nice stuff.
  • use Rack to throttle your API – first reasonable use of Rack i come across.

GitHub (soon-to-be Gemcutter) Treasures

  • cap-recipes – Battle-tested capistrano recipes for ruby, rubygems, apache, passenger, delayed_job, juggernaut, whenever, among other popular tools.
  • active_api – an API layer for ruby.
  • babushka – task automation, i think.
